verses.text: He rose from there and went to the region of Judea and across the Jordan. And again, crowds gathered around him, and as was his custom, he taught them again.
verses.comment: Jesus continues his ministry, drawing crowds and teaching as a rabbi with authority.

verses.text: And Pharisees came to test him, and they asked, 'Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife?'
verses.comment: The Pharisees are trying to trap Jesus with a controversial question rooted in the Mosaic law.

verses.text: He answered them, 'What did Moses command you?'
verses.comment: Jesus refers back to the Torah to bring out the true purpose of the law.

verses.text: They said, 'Moses allowed a man to write a certificate of divorce and to send her away.'
verses.comment: They cite Deuteronomy 24:1, where Moses gives regulations for divorce.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'Because of your hardness of heart he wrote you this commandment.'
verses.comment: Jesus makes clear that divorce was not God's original intention; the command was a concession to human sinfulness.

verses.text: But from the beginning of creation, ‘God made them male and female.’
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Genesis 1:27, grounding marriage in creation itself, not in human customs. This upholds the dignity and unchangeable nature of marriage.

verses.text: ‘For this reason a man shall leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife,’
verses.comment: The unity of marriage is ordained by God, referencing Genesis. Marriage is a divine institution rather than a mere human agreement.

verses.text: ‘and the two shall become one flesh.’ So they are no longer two but one flesh.
verses.comment: Jesus reiterates the indissolubility of marriage. Paul also teaches this in Ephesians 5:31, with Christ's union to the Church as the model.

verses.text: Therefore what God has joined together, let no one separate.
verses.comment: Jesus asserts the binding nature of marriage. The unity is God's work, not human, indicating its sacred and permanent character.

verses.text: And when they were in the house again, the disciples asked him about this matter.
verses.comment: The disciples want further explanation, showing even they struggled with Jesus' strict teaching on marriage.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'Whoever divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery against her.'
verses.comment: Jesus clarifies the seriousness of divorce and remarriage, showing the permanence of marriage in God's eyes.

verses.text: And if she divorces her husband and marries another, she commits adultery.
verses.comment: Jesus asserts equality of responsibility in marriage, demonstrating the high standard he calls his followers to.

verses.text: And they were bringing little children to him, so that he might touch them. But the disciples rebuked them.
verses.comment: Children were considered socially unimportant. The disciples' response shows they still misunderstand Jesus' teaching.

verses.text: But when Jesus saw it, he was indignant and said to them, 'Let the little children come to me; do not hinder them, for the kingdom of God belongs to such as these.'
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the value and innocence of children, showing that the kingdom is a gift, and openness is necessary to receive it.

verses.text: Truly I say to you, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God like a child will never enter it.
verses.comment: 'Receiving' the kingdom signals the need for humble, trusting faith.

verses.text: And he took them into his arms, blessed them, and laid his hands on them.
verses.comment: The gesture of blessing connects to the ancient practice of transmitting blessing through physical touch (see Genesis 48:14).

verses.text: And as he was setting out on his journey, a man ran up, knelt before him, and asked, 'Good Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?'
verses.comment: This man recognizes Jesus as a unique teacher. The question shows concern for eternal life, important in both Old and New Testament (see Dan. 12:2).

verses.text: And Jesus said to him, 'Why do you call me good? No one is good but God alone.'
verses.comment: Jesus subtly draws attention to his divinity by accepting the title ‘Good,’ which is reserved for God (see Psalm 86:5).

verses.text: You know the commandments: ‘Do not murder, Do not commit adultery, Do not steal, Do not bear false witness, Do not defraud, Honor your father and mother.’
verses.comment: Jesus references the Ten Commandments. 'Do not defraud' may be tied to the spirit of the commandment on theft, and points toward justice and fairness.

verses.text: And he said to him, 'Teacher, all these I have kept from my youth.'
verses.comment: The man claims faithfulness to the law, showing his sincere desire for righteousness.

verses.text: And Jesus, looking at him, loved him and said to him, 'You lack one thing: go, sell all you have and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; and come, follow me.'
verses.comment: Jesus invites the man to radical discipleship, showing that following him requires total self-gift. This hints at the call to give up earthly attachments for the sake of the kingdom.

verses.text: But at this, his face fell and he went away sorrowful, for he had great possessions.
verses.comment: Attachment to wealth can hinder following Christ. The sadness shows the cost of discipleship.

verses.text: And Jesus looked around and said to his disciples, 'How difficult it is for those who have riches to enter the kingdom of God!'
verses.comment: Wealth can be a stumbling block to dependence on God.

verses.text: The disciples were amazed at his words. But Jesus said to them again, 'Children, how hard it is to enter the kingdom of God!'
verses.comment: Jesus emphasizes humanity’s need for grace to enter God's kingdom.

verses.text: It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to enter the kingdom of God.
verses.comment: A vivid image expressing the human impossibility of salvation by one’s own merit. Entry to the kingdom requires God’s action.

verses.text: And they were exceedingly astonished and said to him, 'Then who can be saved?'
verses.comment: The disciples realize that by human standards, salvation seems hopeless.

verses.text: Jesus looked at them and said, 'With man it is impossible, but not with God. For all things are possible with God.'
verses.comment: Jesus affirms God's sovereignty and power to save where human effort falls short (cf. Gen. 18:14, Jer. 32:17).

verses.text: Peter began to say to him, 'See, we have left everything and followed you.'
verses.comment: Peter emphasizes the cost of discipleship, expecting recognition for the apostles’ sacrifices.

verses.text: Jesus said, 'Truly I say to you, there is no one who has left house or brothers or sisters or mother or father or children or lands, for my sake and for the gospel's,
verses.comment: Jesus promises that those who make sacrifices for his sake will not lose their reward.

verses.text: who will not receive now in this time a hundred times more—houses and brothers and sisters and mothers and children and lands, with persecutions—and in the age to come eternal life.
verses.comment: Blessings are given here and now in the community of believers, though with persecution. The promise ultimately points to eternal life with God.

verses.text: But many who are first will be last, and the last first.'
verses.comment: God’s criteria for reward are different from worldly expectations. Humility is honored in the kingdom.

verses.text: They were on the road, going up to Jerusalem, and Jesus was walking ahead of them. The disciples were amazed, and those who followed were afraid. And taking the twelve again, he began to tell them what was going to happen to him,
verses.comment: Jesus resolutely heads to Jerusalem, indicating his foreknowledge and acceptance of his mission. This sets the scene for another prophecy of his suffering.

verses.text: saying, 'See, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man will be delivered over to the chief priests and the scribes. They will condemn him to death and deliver him over to the Gentiles.'
verses.comment: Jesus' detailed prophecy points to his Messiahship and his knowledge of the coming Passion. 'Son of Man' is a messianic title from Daniel 7:13-14.

verses.text: 'They will mock him and spit on him, flog him, and kill him. And after three days he will rise.'
verses.comment: Isaiah 50:6 and Psalm 16:10 foreshadow the suffering Messiah and resurrection. Jesus prophesies both in detail.

verses.text: Then James and John, the sons of Zebedee, came to him and said, 'Teacher, we want you to do for us whatever we ask of you.'
verses.comment: James and John seek privilege, showing misunderstanding of the nature of Jesus’ kingdom.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'What do you want me to do for you?'
verses.comment: Jesus patiently invites them to express their desire.

verses.text: And they said to him, 'Grant us to sit, one at your right hand and one at your left, in your glory.'
verses.comment: They are asking for special honor in Jesus’ kingdom, reflecting a misunderstanding of his mission.

verses.text: But Jesus said to them, 'You do not know what you are asking. Are you able to drink the cup that I drink, or to be baptized with the baptism with which I am baptized?'
verses.comment: 'Cup' and 'baptism' refer to Jesus' suffering and death, echoing images in the Psalms and Old Testament.

verses.text: They said to him, 'We are able.' And Jesus said to them, 'The cup that I drink you will drink, and with the baptism with which I am baptized, you will be baptized.'
verses.comment: James and John will share in suffering for Christ. See James’s martyrdom in Acts 12:2.

verses.text: But to sit at my right hand or at my left is not mine to grant, but it is for those for whom it has been prepared.
verses.comment: Jesus points to the Father’s authority and the mystery of predestined glory.

verses.text: And when the ten heard it, they began to be angry with James and John.
verses.comment: The other disciples react out of human rivalry, misunderstanding Christ’s call to humble service.

verses.text: Jesus called them to him and said to them, 'You know that those who are considered rulers of the Gentiles lord it over them, and their great ones exercise authority over them.'
verses.comment: Jesus contrasts worldly leadership with servant leadership.

verses.text: But it shall not be so among you. Whoever would be great among you must be your servant,
verses.comment: True greatness in the kingdom comes through humble service.

verses.text: and whoever would be first among you must be slave of all.
verses.comment: Leaders in the Church are called to lay down their lives for the flock.

verses.text: For even the Son of Man did not come to be served but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many.'
verses.comment: Jesus refers to his death as a ransom, fulfilling Isaiah 53’s prophecy of the suffering servant. Here, Christ reveals his mission: divine service through sacrificial love.

verses.text: And they came to Jericho. And as he was leaving Jericho with his disciples and a large crowd, Bartimaeus, a blind beggar, the son of Timaeus, was sitting by the road.
verses.comment: Bartimaeus' blindness represents both physical and spiritual need. Jericho is a symbolic setting—entry to the promised land.

verses.text: And when he heard it was Jesus of Nazareth, he began to shout, 'Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!'
verses.comment: 'Son of David' is a clear messianic title, affirming Jesus’ kingship and claim to David’s throne (2 Samuel 7:12-14).

verses.text: And many rebuked him, telling him to be silent, but he cried out all the more, 'Son of David, have mercy on me!'
verses.comment: Persistence in faith is highlighted, even when opposed by the crowd.

verses.text: And Jesus stopped and said, 'Call him.' So they called the blind man, saying to him, 'Take heart; get up, he is calling you.'
verses.comment: Jesus’s call is personal and compassionate. His miracles often begin with mercy.

verses.text: And throwing off his cloak, he jumped up and came to Jesus.
verses.comment: Bartimaeus’s response is immediate, symbolizing the putting aside of old ways to follow Christ.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'What do you want me to do for you?' The blind man said, 'Rabboni, let me recover my sight.'
verses.comment: 'Rabboni' is an honorific for a teacher. Bartimaeus’s faith is rooted in recognizing Jesus' authority—a mark of true discipleship.

verses.text: And Jesus said to him, 'Go, your faith has saved you.' Immediately he recovered his sight and followed Jesus on the road.
verses.comment: Jesus affirms that faith brings salvation and healing. Bartimaeus follows Jesus, a model of discipleship—the response to God’s saving action. This miracle fulfills Isaiah 35:5, pointing to the era of the Messiah.
